floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are expected to remain high on the Lower Dorset Stour.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Wimborne and Christchurch.
No further rainfall is forecast for 24 hours.
River levels remain high but are now declining, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains.
We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 04/11/2021,

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.95 m and is falling slowly. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 6.89 m and is falling slowly. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load if this level exceeds 7.86 m, and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m. Further light showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. The River Yeo at Muchelney has been decreasing throughout yesterday, 03/11/21, into today. We are continuing to monitor the situation closely. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 13:00 on Thursday, 04/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Derwent Water Lake levels remain high following recent rainfall with water levels remaining high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Derwentwater and surrounding watercourses.  Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land in locations near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwentwater. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near these watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. With a dry forecast until Saturday levels will continue to recede. We continue to monitor the situation and this message will be updated tomorrow, Thursday 04/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Duddon, Crake and Mill Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Duddon, River Crake, Mill Beck
River Cocker, River Marron, River Derwent
River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River and lake levels remain high as a result of recent rainfall, although they are starting to recede and will continue to recede due to a dry forecast up until Saturday. These include Rivers Brathay, Rothay and Winster and other watercourses, particularly from Grasmere to Grange-over-Sands including low lying areas around Ambleside, Skelwith Bridge, Windermere, Hawkshead, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cark and Cartmel. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near these watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We continue to monitor the situation and this message will be updated tomorrow, Thursday 04/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

The level of Derwent Water remains high following recent heavy rainfall, although levels have started to recede due to dry weather.  With a dry forecast up until Saturday levels will continue to fall. Areas that continue to be at risk of flooding include low-lying land bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. Avoid using low lying roads and footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We will continue to monitor the situation and will update this message tomorrow, Thursday 04/11/2021.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.15 m and is falling slowly. Water will enter Currymoor reservoir via Hookbridge spillway whilst this level exceeds 7.45 m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 5.34 m and is falling slowly. There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m. Pumping is now taking place at Currymoor pumping station, as well as Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations. The two Currymoor pumps will run while river Tone levels allow, to avoid water spilling back into the Moor. No further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 13:00 on Thursday, 04/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: River levels are falling but remain above the Flood Alert threshold at the Sherborne Lake river gauge. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 03/11/21. Areas most at risk are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. No further showers are forecast over the next 24 hours. We are monitoring the situation constantly. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses, plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This flood alert will remain in place today and will be updated by 15:00 tomorrow, Thursday 04/11/21.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and we will re-issue this alert if necessary.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are falling.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Very little rainfall is forecast for the next few days.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

River levels have risen on the River Esk due to rainfall.
Areas most at risk include Low lying land in the Esk Valley, particularly around Ruswarp and some minor roads. .
No further rainfall is forecast and levels are expected to reduce later this morning.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 04/11/2021, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  
We will continue to monitor the forecast and we will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold on 04/11/21. Further showers are possible over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the situation and reissue the alert if necessary.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Derwent has now been issued. Levels have risen in the headwaters of the River Derwent as a result of recent rainfall on Wednesday 3rd November. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected during today, Thursday 4th November. Areas most at risk are low-lying land and roads around Low Marishes. Levels will remain high in this area during today. Levels in Malton are not currently of concern. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through flood water. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.75mAOD at 14:00 on 04/11/21 and 4.90mAOD at 02:15 on 05/11/21.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 80 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 05/11/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely today, Thursday 4th November, between 10:00am and midday. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.71mAODN at 11:00am, on Thursday 4th November, which is 0.16m above tide tables, wind Force 5, north-westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are continuing to monitor the situation. An update to this message will be provided by 3:00pm today.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River and high tide levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.    
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast and the eastern part of the Humber Estuary today, Thursday 4th November between 16:30 and 19:00. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Kilnsea and Spurn Point. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides in the coming days. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by 19:00 on Thursday 4th November 2021.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: Strong winds and spring tides may cause large waves and spray overtopping along the East Yorkshire Coast and the eastern part of the Humber Estuary today, Thursday 4th November between 16:30 and 19:00. The particular areas at risk are exposed areas of the coast around Kilnsea and Spurn Point. Spring tides peak over the weekend, and combined with unsettled weather may result in us issuing this alert for subsequent tides in the coming days. Please be careful along beaches, coastal footpaths and roads in the area, as large waves and sea spray can be dangerous. We will continue to monitor the forecast and levels closely. This message will be updated by 19:00 on Thursday 4th November 2021.

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, Stream Dike, Foss Beck

items.message: The Flood Warning for the North Sea Coast at Hornsea is no longer in force.  The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area. Flood Alerts are still in force for surrounding areas. Tides will remain high and we are continuing to monitor the situation. We will reissue this warning if necessary.

items.description: North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton
items.message: The Flood Alert for the North Sea coast at Skipsea, Hornsea and Mappleton is no longer in force. The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area. Tides remain high and we are continuing to monitor the situation. We will reissue this alert if necessary.

Large and powerful waves are expected to overtop sea defences as a result of high spring tides and strong winds at Beadnell Habour Road North. Tides will be at their highest between 14:00 and 16:30 today, 04/11/2021. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Areas most at risk are beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. Warkworth flood gates remain open, and are not expected to be closed. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation. 
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts. This message will be updated by 18:00 on 04/11/2021, or as the situation changes.
